instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3437: What is 820-3437? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.PM_PWRBTN_L: What is PM_PWRBTN_L? PM_PWRBTN_L refers to the power button signal line. This line is used to initiate the power-on sequence of the laptop. The "L" at the end of "PM_PWRBTN_L" suggests that it is an active-low signal, meaning that when the power button is pressed, the signal is pulled low to initiate the boot sequence..
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.PM_BATLOW_L: What is PM_BATLOW_L? PM_BATLOW_L is a signal that tells the system the battery is too low for it to turn on & keeps it from turning on, when it is low. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.SMC_LID: What is SMC_LID? SMC_LID tells the machine the system is open when it is 3.3v to 3.4v, and closed when it is low such as 0v-0.6v. When this signal is low, the machine may go to sleep or have no backlight. .
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.PPVCC_S0_CPU: What is PPVCC_S0_CPU? The "PPVCC_S0_CPU" power rail is responsible for supplying power to the CPU when the MacBook is fully on, or in the S0 state. This rail is one of the main voltages that the CPU requires for operation. .
definitions.SMC_ADAPTER_EN: What is SMC_ADAPTER_EN? SMC_ADAPTER_EN enables the machine to work off of the power adapter when the proper power adapter is attached. Attacching an 85w Macbook Pro 15” power adapter to a 13” Macbook that requires a 60w power adapter is ok, attaching a 45w Macbook Air power adapter to a 15” macbook Pro that needs an 85w power adapter will result in SMC_ADAPTER_EN missing. .
definitions.PM_RSMRST_L: What is PM_RSMRST_L? The "PM_RSMRST_L" signal, also known as "Resume Reset," is an active-low signal that is part of the power management system in MacBooks. It asserts a reset signal when it is low voltage which is what the _L is for. Is the machine is in a reset stage it will not properly power on..
definitions.PP1V05_S0:
What is PP1V05_S0? The PP1V05_S0 power rail is for various components on the logic board that require a 1.05V supply voltage in the S0 (on) state. This voltage rail is likely to be used by the CPU (for VCCIO), PCH (Platform Controller Hub).

.
definitions.PP1V5_S0: What is PP1V5_S0? PP1V5_S0 is a 1.5v power rail present when the machine is in an S0 working state.
definitions.PP1V2_S3: What is PP1V2_S3? PP1V2_S3 is a 1.2v power rail present when the machine is in an S3 suspend to RAM state.
definitions.PM_PCH_PWROK: What is PM_PCH_PWROK? PM_PCH_PWROK is usually created by U1950, a 74LVC2G08GT chip and is necessary for the machine to wake from an S5 and S4 state and turn on. This signal will be present if ALL_SYS_PWRGD, CPU_VR_PGOOD, PP3V3_S0, and PP3V42_G3H are present. When this signal is not present or intermittent, usually pin 8 on U1950 for PP3V42_G3H is corroded..
definitions.PP1V8_S3: What is PP1V8_S3? The PP1V8_S3 signal in the MacBook schematic is a power rail that provides a voltage of 1.8 volts during the S3 power state. The S3 state, often referred to as "suspend to RAM," is a low-power mode where the computer saves the session's state to RAM, allowing for quicker wake-up times compared to a full shutdown..
definitions.PP1V05_SUS: What is PP1V05_SUS? The PP1V05_SUS signal in the MacBook schematic is a power rail that supplies 1.05 volts, typically used in a suspended (SUS) state of the laptop. This state is a low-power mode where essential system functions are maintained, but the majority of the system is powered down..
definitions.PP0V6_S0_DDRVTT: What is PP0V6_S0_DDRVTT? Power rail for RAM. .
definitions.PM_SYSRST_L: What is PM_SYSRST_L? PM_SYSRST_L is a system reset signal present when it is low, _L means the signal asserts itself when the voltage is low. This signal needs to be high for the system to exit reset mode & turn on properly. .
definitions.PM_PCH_SYSPWROK: What is PM_PCH_SYSPWROK? This is a typo of PM_PCH_SYS_PWROK When you see PM_PCH_SYSPWROK, assume they meant to type PM_PCH_SYS_PWROK.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b no chime no image
threads.message:
Hey guys. This one has no chime no boot. doesn't seem to have any liquid. all the voltages I have measured look good as I was probing around I found <RESISTOR>R7630</RESISTOR> is at 6.2v seems a bit crazy! I measured and from <CHIP>U7600</CHIP> pin 15 there is 6.2v on <SIGNAL>P1V0S0_VBST</SIGNAL> & <SIGNAL>P1V05S0_BOOT_RC</SIGNAL>

There is fan spin
light on charger is present
also activity on usb is present

anyways voltages;
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 8.63v
pp3v42 3.46v
ppvrtc 3.34v
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> 5.1v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> 3.3v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> 3.3v
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_S3</SIGNAL> 1.79v
<SIGNAL>PP1V2_S3</SIGNAL> 1.2v
<SIGNAL>PP1V05_S0</SIGNAL> 1.05v
<SIGNAL>PP1V05_SUS</SIGNAL> 1.05v
<SIGNAL>PP1V5_S0</SIGNAL> 1.5v
<SIGNAL>PP0V6_S0_DDRVTT</SIGNAL> 0.6v
<SIGNAL>PP1V05_S0</SIGNAL> 1.05v
<SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> 1.762v

<SIGNAL>SMC_LID</SIGNAL> 3.4v
<SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> 3.4v
<SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL> 3.42v
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS</SIGNAL> 3.3v
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> 3.3v
<SIGNAL>PM_SYSRST_L</SIGNAL> 3.3v
<SIGNAL>PM_PCH_PWROK</SIGNAL> 3.4v
<SIGNAL>PM_PCH_SYSPWROK</SIGNAL> 3.45v
<SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL> 3.3v
<SIGNAL>PM_SYSRST_L</SIGNAL> 3.3v
<SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> 3.3v
<SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> 3.4v
<SIGNAL>PUT_RESET_L</SIGNAL> 3.3v

not sure what else.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b no chime no image
threads.message:
"I found <RESISTOR>R7630</RESISTOR> is at 6.2v seems a bit crazy! I measured and from <CHIP>U7600</CHIP> pin 15 there is 6.2v on <SIGNAL>P1V0S0_VBST</SIGNAL> & <SIGNAL>P1V05S0_BOOT_RC</SIGNAL>"
Not crazy at all, just correct...

"also activity on usb is present"
Can you confirm with pendrive OSX with LED Link?
If yes, try PRAM reset.
Then post voltage for J8300, pins 2/3, 14, 15, 16, 18/19.
Check if you get voltage at least in the first seconds.
Test external video too.

You can also try new BIOS.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b no chime no image
threads.message:
usb activity i usually just plug in usb mouse see if laser turn on...

but i also try with osx usb drive and flashing!
i also try pram.

i think u mean pin 3/4 because pin 2 no connect?

anyways
3 25.35
4 25.36
14 2.6
15 3.2
16 3.2
18 3.3
19 3.3

in first few seconds no voltage. i will test external after lunch thanks
